items.title: Quebec’s language law causes confusion for English speakers, federal commissioner says
items.summary_auto: Changes to Quebec’s French-language law are creating confusion for English-speaking residents trying to access services, according to a midterm report from Canada’s commissioner of official languages.

items.title: Thomas King revelation ‘a blemish on the entire Canadian literary industry,’ says Niigaan Sinclair
NHL catch-up: Canadian players hot, Canadian teams cold
items.summary_auto: CBC Sports' daily newsletter checks in on some NHL trends at the quarter mark of the season, including a great start by some top Canadian players and a bad one for most Canadian teams.

items.title: Pope Leo headed to Turkey and Lebanon for 1st trip abroad as leader of Catholic Church
items.summary_auto: Pope Leo will embark on his first trip outside Italy as the leader of the Catholic Church on Thursday, traveling to Turkey and Lebanon, where he is expected to make appeals for peace in the region and urge unity among long-divided Christian churches.

items.title: Canada collected over $5.4B in cannabis tax revenue since legalization
items.summary_auto: Ottawa and the provinces raked in more than $5.4 billion in cannabis tax revenue since the drug was legalized for recreational use in October 2018.

items.title: Can 3D printing limbs help Gaza's war wounded?
items.summary_auto: Gaza now has more child amputees per capita than anywhere else in the world. CBC News chief correspondent Adrienne Arsenault meets with organizations in Cairo trying to help, including a Canadian non-profit organization hoping to provide 3D printed prosthetics.

items.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro begins serving 27-year prison sentence
items.summary_auto: Brazil's Supreme Court on  Tuesday ordered former president Jair Bolsonaro to begin a  prison sentence of more than 27 years for plotting a coup in 2022, according to a court document.

items.title: After ‘poring over’ docs, new N.L. premier says deficit likely higher than previously reported
items.summary_auto: Newfoundland and Labrador Premier Tony Wakeham says the state of the province’s finances is dire, and believes the deficit is higher than $620 million reported in a fiscal update in August.

items.title: Abducted Nigerian schoolgirls rescued, president says
items.summary_auto: All 24 schoolgirls who were  abducted by armed assailants from a school last week in Kebbi  in northwestern Nigeria have been rescued, the country's president announced Tuesday.

items.title: Quebec coroner finds gaps in medical care for man who sought MAID after bedsores
items.summary_auto: A Quebec coroner issued 31 recommendations in relation to the death of Normand Meunier, who sought a medically assisted death in March 2024 after his severe bedsores were made significantly worse by an ER stay in Saint-Jérôme.

items.title: Israel isn't sure latest human remains returned by Hamas are those of a hostage
items.summary_auto: Israel on Tuesday said it received human remains that Palestinian militants handed over to the Red Cross, but it was not immediately clear if they were one of three hostages remaining in the Gaza Strip.

items.title: Campbell's exec on leave after allegedly mocking 'poor people' who eat its soup
items.summary_auto: A lawsuit filed by a former security analyst at Campbell's alleges he was fired for reporting inappropriate conduct by a senior executive, including an hour-long rant in which the executive allegedly called the company's products "s--t for f---ing poor people" in a secret recording.

items.title: Proposed B.C. class action claims governments misled property owners in light of Cowichan Tribes decision
items.summary_auto: A proposed class action lawsuit accuses the federal and B.C. governments of keeping property owners in the dark amid the Cowichan Tribes Aboriginal title ruling.

items.title: 14 Alberta MLAs are now facing recall drives. Here's how the process works
MPs recommend criminalizing coercive control to combat intimate partner violence
items.summary_auto: Members of Parliament have revived calls for Canada to criminalize the concept of coercive control as a way of combating intimate partner violence, after a previous bill died when Parliament was dissolved.

items.title: Colleen Jones, champion curler and CBC reporter, dead at 65
Swimmer Penny Oleksiak banned from competition until 2027 as part of anti-doping regulations
Ontario ballet's stolen Nutcracker set recovered
items.summary_auto: A moving truck loaded with 'irreplaceable' sets and backdrops for an Ontario-wide tour of The Nutcracker has been found one day after it was reported stolen, ahead of the production’s show in Burlington, Ont.

items.title: Indigenous-led Red Dress Alert program must be implemented in Manitoba 'without delay': report
items.summary_auto: A Manitoba Red Dress Alert program must launch no later than June 2026 and be implemented through an Indigenous-led independent organization, says a report released Tuesday.

items.title: Mystery man who placed flag and saluted Kitchener, Ont., home on Remembrance Day identified
items.summary_auto: Reg Kirby takes a stroll around his old neighbourhood in Kitchener every Remembrance Day. This year, a security camera caught him placing a flag in the lawn of a home in the area and saluting. He says he lived in the home as a child and his annual tradition honours his parents and the sacrifices they made for him and his brother, Kerry.

items.title: Ontario proposes harsher penalties for dangerous driving, including lifetime bans
items.summary_auto: The proposed law, inspired by the death of a man killed in an alleged dangerous driver incident this summer, would enact lifetime driving bans for those convicted of dangerous driving causing death.

items.title: McGill University's decision to cut 25 sports teams called 'unfortunate' by U Sports CEO
items.summary_auto: U Sports chief executive officer Pierre Arsenault says McGill University's decision to cut 25 sports teams following the 2025-26 season is "unfortunate."

items.title: Quebec economic update includes tax breaks for workers, use of Green Fund to tackle debt
items.summary_auto: Finance Minister Eric Girard plans to help workers save $1.8 billion over five years through a reduction of contribution rates to the Quebec Pension Plan (QPP) and Quebec Parental Insurance Plan (QPIP).

items.title: Sudanese army, paramilitary fighters haven't signed onto truce plan, Trump adviser says
items.summary_auto: The United States has presented Sudan's warring parties with a proposal for a truce but neither side has formally accepted it, U.S. envoy Massad Boulos said Tuesday, as the army accused its rivals of staging an attack despite declaring a ceasefire.

items.title: Court order prevents L.A. coroner from releasing details of teen's body found in singer d4vd's Tesla
items.summary_auto: Los Angeles police have blocked the county coroner's office from releasing details about the death of a teen girl whose body was found in the trunk of a car registered to the singer d4vd, the medical examiner's office said on Monday.

items.title: Meet the B.C. residents hosting whale detection devices on their properties
items.summary_auto: From infrared thermal cameras to hydrophones, these B.C. residents offered up space on their properties as researchers look to help safeguard marine mammals.

items.title: Lheidli T'enneh First Nation bans herbicide use across north-central B.C.
items.summary_auto: The ban takes particular aim at use of glyphosate in forestry, though it's not clear if it will impact private land.

items.title: Endangered barn owl makes 'extremely rare' appearance in Calgary
items.summary_auto: The barn owl, one of Canada's most endangered owls, isn't native to Alberta and is considered extremely rare anywhere in the province, which is why wildlife photographers were shocked when one made a surprise appearance in a Calgary park.

items.title: Caregiver wants apology after off-duty RCMP officer arrested woman with intellectual delay
Complaint filed about off-duty RCMP officer who arrested woman with intellectual delay
items.summary_auto: A complaint process is underway for an RCMP officer who arrested an intellectually delayed woman and removed her from a social centre, while off duty and in a different police jurisdiction.

items.title: AI could watch Ottawa's transit cameras for crime, emergencies
items.summary_auto: OC Transpo is looking to use artificial intelligence (AI) to alert special constables to crime and emergencies occurring within the agency's vehicles and facilities, Ottawa city councillors have heard.

items.title: Tracking Palestinian, Israeli deaths since the Gaza ceasefire went into effect
items.summary_auto: In the first six weeks since Israel and Palestinian militant group Hamas reached a truce deal aimed at ending their two-year war, Israeli attacks in Gaza have been reported almost daily.

items.title: Some wins for multilateralism at the G20 — and big questions about its long-term future
items.summary_auto: The G20 summit is supposed to be the pinnacle of multilateralism: the idea that nations can co-operate, compromise and co-ordinate for the greater good. But a lot has changed in the past two decades.

items.title: How Dancing with the Stars made all the right moves with Gen Z
items.summary_auto: Dancing with the Stars recently celebrated its 20th anniversary — but that's not why it's been the talk of Instagram, TikTok, Twitter and, yes, water coolers everywhere this season. Blending nostalgia with a new kind of stardom, the show has successfully reimagined the dance competition for a new generation.
